DOC.HEAD: Baker Says No U.S. Objections If Soviets Intervene in Romania
With PM-Romania Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A top Soviet official rules out military intervention in Romania, but Secretary of State James A. Baker III says the Bush administration would not object if Soviet troops helped revolutionaries battling loyalists to deposed communist despot Nicolae Ceausescu. Romanians are ``attempting to put off the yoke of a very, very oppressive and repressive dictatorship, so I think that we would be inclined probably to follow the lead, follow the example of France, who today has said that if the Warsaw Pact felt it necessary to intervene on behalf of the opposition, that it would support that,'' Baker said Sunday on the NBC-TV program ``Meet the Press.'' Dutch government officials also said they would not oppose Soviet or Warsaw Pact military intervention if it would ``support the aspirations of the Romanian people.'' However, Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryshkov said Saturday that sending the Red Army to Romania would be ``impermissible'' and a repetition of past mistakes. U.S. officials by late Sunday detected no sign of foreign intervention in Romania, where fierce fighting continued between Ceausescu backers and the National Salvation Committee, said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. ``It is obviously our hope that the pro-reform forces will win, but it's still a very hairy situation, a great deal of violence, and I would think that the outcome is probably still in doubt,'' Cheney said on the ABC-TV program ``This Week With David Brinkley.'' ``We haven't seen any sign of any outside intervention,'' said Cheney. President Bush, speaking briefly to reporters in Washington, said the British ambassador to Romania took refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Bucharest because his embassy was destroyed. ``The British Embassy was razed and so the British ambassador is now our guest, I understand. So that has been a very traumatic pre-Christmas uprising,'' Bush said after speaking by telephone with the U.S. ambassador to Bucharest, Alan Green. The French offered to send volunteers to fight for Romania's National Salvation Committee. Baker, asked whether America was prepared to send U.S. troops into Romania, said any such decision would rest with Bush. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters later, ``We don't have any indication that there is a chance of the Soviets' going in, at least not at this time. So we don't expect that to occur.'' Asked about Baker's comment, Fitzwater added: ``We could see a situation that might be severe enough where there'd be a need to help establish law and order.'' But he said that it ``certainly is not necessary now and does not appear to be necessary.'' Baker said U.S. officials were in contact with the revolutionaries but he declined to give specifics. ``We've had some discussions with representatives of the new group and we've been encouraging in our comments and frankly we would like to see this be resolved in as peaceful a fashion as possible, but we think it is important that there be a move toward freedom and greater political pluralism in Romania,'' Baker said.
